questions.text: Patient met with an accident where the dashboard of the car hits anteriorly over the knee while sitting besides the driver and presents with severe pain and deformity of the hip. Most probable deformity of hip to occur will be:
questions.solution:
Dashboard Injuries cause Posterior Dislocation of Hip which Presents with Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation. (Remembered as FADIR)

Posterior Dislocation of the Hip:

  1. Definition
    • The head of the femur is displaced out of the acetabulum in a posterior direction. In about 50% of cases, this dislocation is associated with a fracture of the posterior lip of the acetabulum, known as a fracture-dislocation.
  2. Diagnosis

Clinical Features:

  • History of severe trauma, such as a car accident.
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling.
    • Deformity characterized by:
      • Flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip. (Option B)
      • Shortening of the affected leg.
  • Palpation: The femoral head may be felt in the gluteal region.
  • Routine pelvic X-rays are recommended in patients with femoral fractures to rule out associated hip dislocation.

Radiological Features:

  • The femoral head appears displaced out of the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, making the lesser trochanter less visible.
  • Shenton's line is disrupted.
  • Comparison X-ray of the opposite hip may be useful.
  • CT Scan may be required to assess associated fractures.

Option A - ABD +ER is seen in anterior hip dislocation but not FLX.

Option C - Neck of femur & sub trochanteric femur fracture shows Shortening with ER.

Option D - None of the above is incorrect because it presents with Flexion, Adduction and internal Rotation as Given in Option B.

Key takeaways: Dashboard Injuries cause Posterior Dislocation of Hip which Presents with Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation. (Remembered as FADIR)

questions.text: Patient presents to the emergency ward with an injury over the left tibia. He has around a 3 cm laceration wound over the fracture site. X-ray shows a simple transverse fracture of the left tibia. This injury is classified as:
questions.solution:
Gustillo Anderson classification:

Management of Open Fractures

An open (compound) fracture occurs when there is a break in the overlying skin and soft tissues, creating communication between the fracture site and the external environment. This condition can lead to several complications:

  1. Infection of Bone
    • Risk: The wound is susceptible to contamination from external bacteria, leading to osteomyelitis (bone infection).
  2. Challenges with Traditional Management
    • Small Wounds: Can be managed through a window in a plaster cast.
    • Large Wounds:
      • May be difficult to manage with traditional methods.
      • Wounds can complicate or prevent operative fixation of the fracture.
  3. Problems Related to Fracture Union
    • Non-Union and Malunion: Common in open fractures due to several factors:
      • Loss of Bone Fragment: A piece of bone may be lost from the wound, creating a gap that predisposes to non-union.
      • Loss of Fracture Hematoma: The hematoma, which has osteogenic potential, may be lost, affecting healing.
      • Loss of Vascular Cover: The absence of soft tissue cover, crucial for fracture union, can impede healing.
      • Secondary Infection: The bone may become infected, further hindering union.
  4. Importance of Careful Management
    • Due to these potential complications, open fractures require meticulous and comprehensive management throughout the treatment process.

(Option A, B, C and D) As wound size is >1cm and the fracture pattern is simple, this injury is classified under type II fracture.

Key Takeaway: As wound size is >1cm and the fracture pattern is simple, this injury is classified under type II Gustilo Anderson fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following fracture patterns has the best healing potential irrespective of the treatment modality?
questions.solution:
Spiral fracture has the highest surface area, hence maximum healing potential.

Classification of Fractures Based on Pattern

  1. Transverse Fracture: (Option B)
    • Description: Fracture line is perpendicular to the long axis of the bone.
    • Cause: Typically caused by a tapping or bending force.
  2. Oblique Fracture: (Option A)
    • Description: Fracture line is oblique.
    • Cause: Resulting from a bending force that also has a component along the long axis of the bone.
  3. Spiral Fracture: (Option C)
    • Description: Fracture line runs spirally in more than one plane.
    • Cause: Primarily caused by a twisting force.
  4. Comminuted Fracture: (Option D)
    • Description: Fracture consisting of multiple fragments.
    • Cause: Resulting from a crushing or compression force along the long axis of the bone.
  5. Segmental Fracture:
    • Description: Two fractures in one bone at different levels.
  6. Combination Fractures:
    • Note: A fracture may exhibit a combination of two or more patterns (e.g., a comminuted fracture that is primarily transverse).

Option A, B & D: Sequence of Fracture union Potential: Spiral (Option C) > Oblique (Option A) > Transverse (Option B) > Comminuted (Option D)

Key takeaways: Pattern of fracture in decreasing order of union potential

Spiral fracture (most) >>>> Oblique fracture >>>> Transverse fracture >>>> Comminuted fracture >>>> Segmental fracture >>>> Open fracture (Least).

questions.text: A young volleyball player dislocated his left shoulder anteriorly while playing which was reduced in an emergency. After this he started having recurrent dislocations while doing simple day to day activities as well. Select false statement:
questions.solution:
Bankart Lesion:

  • Definition: Avulsion of the anterior-inferior capsulolabral complex (Option B), extending into the scapular periosteum with rupture of periosteal tissue.
  • Occurrence: Found in 90% of patients with recurrent anterior shoulder instability.
  • Originally described by Bankart as the essential lesion for anterior shoulder instability.

Other Capsulolabral Lesions:

  • Perthes Lesion - Avulsion of anterior-inferior glenoid-labral complex with preservation of medial scapular neck periosteum
  • ALPSA (Anterior Labroligamentous Periosteal Sleeve Avulsion) Lesion (Option C)
    • Avulsion of anterior-inferior glenolabral complex with stripping of medial scapular neck periosteum but preservation of a medial hinge; loose fragment subsequently scars medially down scapular neck
  • HAGL (Humeral Avulsion of the Glenohumeral Ligaments) Lesion: (Option D)
    • Incidence: 1% to 9% of cases.
    • Avulsion of glenohumeral ligaments from their humerus-side attachment
    • Treatment: Traditionally required open repair; newer arthroscopic techniques are being developed.

Osseous Pathoanatomy:

  • Glenoid Bone Loss:
    • Occurs in almost every patient with anterior shoulder instability.
    • Types:
      • Bony Bankart lesion (identifiable fragment with capsule-labral structures)
      • Impaction and erosion.
    • Presence: 40% in first dislocations, 85% in recurrent dislocations.
    • Significant bone loss (20%-25% of glenoid width, approximately 6-8 mm) is associated with higher recurrence rates post-Bankart repair.
    • Bony Bankart fragment absorbs rapidly within 1 year.
  • Hill-Sachs Lesion: (Option A)
    • Definition: Posterior-superior humeral head injury. (Option C)
    • Occurrence:
      • 40% in recurrent subluxations without dislocations.
      • 90% in first dislocations.
      • Nearly 100% in recurrent dislocations.

Option A & B: Bankart's lesion: Dislocation causes stripping of the glenoid labrum along with the periosteum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck which is best picked up on MRI.

Option C: Hill-Sachs lesion: This is a depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant, caused by impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid on the head as it dislocates.

Option D: The shoulder is also the commonest joint to undergo recurrent dislocation.

Key takeaways:

  • Bankart's lesion: Dislocation causes stripping of the glenoid labrum along with the periosteum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck which is best picked up on MRI.
  • Hill-Sachs lesion: This is a depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant, caused by impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid on the head as it dislocates.

questions.text: Select false statement about myositis ossificans:
questions.solution:
Myositis Ossificans (Post-Traumatic Ossification)

Overview

Myositis ossificans is the ossification of the hematoma surrounding a joint, resulting in a mass of bone that restricts joint movement, often completely.

Causes

  • Severe Joint Injury: Particularly when the joint capsule and periosteum are stripped from the bones due to violent displacement of fragments.
  • Age Factor: More common in children due to the loosely attached periosteum.
  • Common Sites: Frequently occurs around the elbow joint.
  • Associated Conditions: Higher incidence in patients with prolonged or permanent neuronal damage (e.g., from head injuries) and those with paraplegia.
  • Exacerbating Factors: Massage following trauma can aggravate myositis. (Option C)

Consequences

  • Joint Stiffness: Bone formation leads to stiffness, either from capsule thickening or from bone obstructing movement.
  • Extreme Cases: In severe cases, bone may bridge the joint, resulting in complete loss of movement (extra-articular ankylosis).

Radiological Features

  • Active Myositis: Characterized by fluffy margins of the bone mass.
  • Mature Myositis: Appears trabeculated with well-defined margins.

Treatment

  • Initial Care: Rest the limb and avoid massage. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may be prescribed in the early active stage. (Option B)
  • Physiotherapy: In late stages, physiotherapy may help regain movement.
  • Surgical Options: Surgical excision of the matured myositic mass may be considered to restore movement (Option D)

Option A: It is particularly common around the elbow joint. hence Option A is false.

Option B: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may be prescribed in the early active stage.

Option C: Massage following trauma can aggravate myositis.

Option D: Surgical excision of the matured myositic mass may be considered to restore movement.

Key takeaways:

  • Myositis ossification is ossification of the haematoma around a joint, resulting in the formation of a mass of bone restricting joint movements, often completely.
  • It is particularly common around the elbow joint.
  • Massage following trauma is a factor known to aggravate myositis.
  • In the early active stage of myositis the limb should be rested, and NSAID (Indomethacin 75mg SR/25 mg TDS) is given.
  • In some cases, once the myositic mass matures, surgical excision of the bone mass may help regain movement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man involved in a motorcycle crash is brought to the emergency department with a displaced, closed, proximal-third tibia fracture. What is the most sensitive early clinical finding of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pain on passive stretch is thought to be the most sensitive finding in awake patients.

Compartment Syndrome

Diagnosis

  • Occurs when intracompartmental pressure exceeds capillary pressure, impeding nutrient and waste exchange.
  • Frequently missed complications of trauma.
  • Diagnosis Methods:
    • Clinical evaluation.
    • Pressure monitor: Abnormal if pressure is within 30 mm Hg of diastolic pressure (ΔP).

Clinical Hallmarks

  • Early Signs:
    • Pain out of proportion to the injury.
    • Pain with passive stretching of the affected muscle. (Option B)
  • Late Signs:
    • Paresthesias (tingling or numbness). (Option D)
    • Paralysis - Motor weakness.
  • Less Common Findings:
    • Pulselessness and pallor, which suggest arterial compromise rather than compartment syndrome. (Option C)

Important Considerations

  • Timing:
    • If not treated within 4-6 hours, permanent damage can occur.
  • Intraoperative Considerations:
    • Diastolic blood pressure during anesthesia can be approximately 18 mm Hg lower than baseline, potentially causing misleading ΔP values.

Treatment

  • Emergent Decompression:
    • Fasciotomy is required to relieve pressure.
    • Technique:
      • In a two-incision fasciotomy, the medial approach involves releasing the soleus to access the deep posterior compartment.

Consequences of Untreated Compartment Syndrome

  • Common sequelae include claw toes and hand contractures due to ischemic damage.

Option A: Pressure of 40 mm Hg may be significant, but this is not an absolute criteria and depends on diastolic blood pressure, with a ΔP of less than 35 being accepted as significant.

Option C & D: The other options are late findings of compartment syndrome.

Key takeaways:

5 P's in compartment syndrome

  • Pain on passive stretch
  • Paralysis
  • Pallor
  • Paresthesia
  • Pulselessness

questions.text: External fixation is used most often for which of the following?
questions.solution:
External Fixator

Overview

An external fixator is a medical device used to stabilize fractures by holding the bone in a steel frame outside the limb. This technique is particularly useful for managing open fractures where internal fixation is not feasible due to the risk of infection. The fixator consists of pins inserted percutaneously into the bone, which are then connected externally to a bar using clamps.

Types of External Fixators

  1. Pin Fixators
    • Description: Utilizes 3-4 mm sized pins inserted through the bone.
    • Configuration: Pins are stabilized outside the bone using a system of tubular rods and clamps (see Fig-3.5a).
    • Applications: Commonly used for simple and complex fracture patterns where strong stability is needed.
  2. Ring Fixators
    • Description: Employs thin 'K' wires (1-2 mm) passed through the bone.
    • Configuration: Wires are secured externally using circular rings, which allow for precise adjustments and dynamic corrections.
    • Applications: Often used in complex fractures, deformity corrections, and limb lengthening procedures.

Advantages

  • Minimizes Infection Risk: Particularly beneficial in open fractures where traditional internal fixation may pose a higher risk of infection.
  • Versatility: Can be adjusted externally, allowing for dynamic correction of alignment and rotation during the healing process.

Considerations

  • Requires careful monitoring of pin sites to prevent infection.
  • Regular adjustments may be needed to maintain optimal alignment and stability.

Option A, B & D: Although external fixators are used for all the situations (options A, B, C and D) given, external fixation is primarily used for temporization of fractures (Option C) and occasionally for definitive treatment these days as better implants are available.

Key takeaways:

Indications

  • Open fractures with a high risk of infection.
  • Severe soft tissue injuries where internal fixation is not possible.
  • Situations requiring gradual bone transport or deformity correction.

questions.text: Volkmann ischemic contracture (VIC) is a classic complication of untreated acute compartment syndrome in the forearm. Which muscles are the most likely to be affected by this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Long-Term Sequelae of Untreated Acute Compartment Syndrome

Overview

  • Primary Consequences: Muscle fibrosis and Volkmann ischemic contracture.
  • Etiology: Result from unrecognized or untreated acute compartment syndrome leading to advanced myonecrosis and muscle fibrosis.

Volkmann Ischemic Contracture

  • Definition: A classic sequelae of untreated compartment syndrome, particularly in the forearm, characterized by irreversible muscle and nerve damage.

Affected Muscles (Option A, B, C and D)

  • Most Vulnerable:
    • Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP)
    • Flexor Pollicis Longus (FPL)

Classification

  1. Mild Form:
    • Presentation: Mild flexion contractures at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.
    • Function: Preserved strength and sensation.
  2. Moderate to Severe Forms:
    • Presentation:
      • Worsening contractures affecting multiple joints.
      • Significant sensorimotor deficits.
    • Complications:
      • Chronic pain.
      • Severe hand dysfunction.
      • Intrinsic-minus or Claw Hand Deformity: Characteristic of severe cases, resulting from imbalance between the intrinsic and extrinsic hand muscles.

Treatment Options

  1. Contracture Release and Tendon Transfers:
    • Indicated to improve function in cases of moderate to severe contractures.
    • Goals: Limited functional improvement, especially in severe forms.
  2. Muscle Slides:
    • Utilized to address muscle shortening and improve joint mobility.
  3. Nerve Decompression:
    • Recommended for patients experiencing chronic neuropathic pain.
    • Indication: When muscle fibrosis causes extrinsic compression on already compromised peripheral nerves.
  4. Free Innervated Gracilis Muscle Transfer:
    • Considered in selected severe cases to restore some hand function.

Option A, B & D: Superficial muscle like Flexor digitorium superficialis is not affected hence all 3 are incorrect options.

Key takeaways

  • Early recognition and treatment of compartment syndrome are crucial to prevent long-term sequelae such as Volkmann ischemic contracture.
  • FDP and FPL are most vulnerable to contracture.
  • Surgical interventions aim to restore function, but outcomes are often limited, especially in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman got her arm injured as she placed her upper limb outside the window of a moving vehicle and sustained a spiral lower third humerus fracture. She is unable to actively extend her wrist or long fingers and notes numbness in her first dorsal web space. What is the most likely cause of her nerve dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Commonest complication of Humeral Shaft Fractures

Nerve Injury

  • Commonly Affected Nerve: Radial nerve
    • Type of Injury: Typically neurapraxia (stretching leading to temporary nerve damage). (Option A,B,C and D)
    • Causes of Injury:
      • At the time of fracture.
      • During manipulation of the fracture.
      • During healing (nerve entrapment in the callus).
  • Special Fracture Type:
    • Holstein-Lewis Fracture:
      • A spiral fracture at the junction of the middle and distal third of the humerus.
      • Frequently associated with radial nerve palsy.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Motor Deficits:
      • Paralysis of wrist, finger, and thumb extensors (wrist drop).
      • Paralysis of brachioradialis and supinator muscles.
    • Sensory Changes:
      • Loss of sensation in a small area on the radial side of the back of the hand (first dorsal web space).

Treatment

  • Early Cases:
    • Closed Fractures: Nerve usually recovers spontaneously.
    • Open Fractures: Surgical exploration is often necessary.
  • Neglected Cases / Complex Injuries:
    • Tendon transfers are performed if nerve repair is impractical.

Tendon Transfer Procedure: Modified Jones Transfer

  • Objective: Use muscles innervated by the median and ulnar nerves to substitute for lost wrist and finger functions.
  • Tendon Transfers:

Key takeaways:

Although certain fracture patterns in the humerus (spiral distal third- the Holstein-Lewis pattern) are more likely to be associated with nerve injuries, the mechanism for most nerve palsies associated with fractures is stretch.

  • A special type of humerus fracture, where there is a spiral fracture at the junction of the middle and distal third, is commonly known to be associated with a radial nerve palsy. This is called the Holstein Lewis fracture.
  • The radial nerve injury results in paralysis of the wrist, finger and thumb extensors (wrist drop), brachioradialis and the supinator. There is a sensory change in a small area on the radial side of the back of the hand.

questions.text: Knee dislocations can be associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Injury Considerations

  • Knee Dislocation:
    • Requires significant soft tissue injury.
    • Typically involves ruptures of at least three of four major ligamentous structures:
      • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL)
      • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL)
      • Collateral ligaments
      • Capsular elements and menisci may also be injured.

Vascular Anatomy

  • Popliteal Vascular Bundle:
    • Courses through a fibrous tunnel at the adductor hiatus.
    • In the popliteal fossa, five geniculate branches are given off.
    • Runs deep to the soleus muscle through another fibrous canal.
    • Vulnerable to tenting and injury during dislocation.

Associated Fractures

  • Common associated fractures include:
    • Tibial eminence
    • Tibial tubercle
    • Fibular head or neck
    • Capsular avulsions

Option A & B: There is an increased risk for vascular injury with an associated dislocation, and by definition a ligament must tear for the knee to dislocate.

Option C: Although less common than ligamentous injury, bony injuries, especially compression and avulsion fractures, do occur.

Key takeaways:

  • Knee dislocations are often the result of complex forces acting across the joint. They can occur with low-energy mechanisms, particularly in obese patients.
  • There is an increased risk for vascular injury with an associated dislocation, and by definition a ligament must tear for the knee to dislocate.
  • Although less common than ligamentous injury, bony injuries, especially compression and avulsion fractures, do occur.

choices.text: Its life threatening sequelae is pulmonary embolism
It is commonly seen in spinal, pelvic and long bone fractures
Passive plantar flexion increases calf pain in DVT which is called Homan's sign
It is also associated with elective surgeries like knee arthroscopy and THR.

questions.text: In view of deep vein thrombosis; all are true except:
questions.solution:
Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism

Overview:

  • DVT is a common complication of lower limb and spinal injuries, often due to immobility leading to venous stasis and thrombosis.
  • Pulmonary Embolism (PE) can result from DVT, particularly when clots form above the knee. This is a life-threatening complication that typically occurs 4-5 days post-injury.

Causes:

  • Immobilization after trauma or surgery.
  • Manipulation of the thigh during surgery.
  • Venous stasis from prolonged immobility.
  • Inherent patient factors such as obesity and advanced age.

Symptoms and Diagnosis:

  • DVT Signs: Leg swelling, calf tenderness, and positive Homan's sign (pain on passive dorsiflexion of the ankle).
  • PE Symptoms: Tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: Venography for DVT; clinical observation for PE.

Prevention:

  • Pharmacologic Agents: Heparin and newer anticoagulants.
  • Mechanical Measures: Leg exercises, compression garments, and limb elevation.
  • Early Mobilization: Internal fixation of fractures allows early movement, reducing DVT risk.

Treatment:

  • DVT: Limb elevation, elastic bandages, and anticoagulant therapy.
  • PE: Respiratory support and heparin therapy.

Option A: DVT proximal to the knee is a common cause of life threatening complication of pulmonary embolism.

Option B: DVT is a common complication associated with lower limb injuries and with pelvic and spinal injuries.

Option C: The calf tenderness may get exaggerated by passive dorsiflexion of the ankle (Homan's sign). (Not Plantar Flexion)

Option D: Most common complication after knee arthroscopy and THR is DVT.

Key takeaways:

  • DVT Signs: Leg swelling, calf tenderness, and positive Homan's sign (pain on passive dorsiflexion of the ankle).
  • PE Symptoms: Tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: Venography for DVT; clinical observation for PE.

questions.text: A 45 yr female sustained a high velocity road traffic accident after which she complains of severe pain in her left hip region. The hip is in flexion, adduction internal rotation with gross shortening. She is not able to move her ankle or knee joint as well. Best investigation to do in this case is?
questions.solution:
Posterior Dislocation of the Hip

Overview:

  • Occurs when the femoral head is displaced posteriorly out of the acetabulum.
  • Often associated with a fracture of the posterior acetabular lip, known as a fracture-dislocation.

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Caused by a force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed.
  • Commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents (dashboard injury) when the knee strikes the dashboard, transmitting force to the femur and dislocating the hip.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Features:
    • Severe trauma history with pain, swelling, and deformity (hip in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation).
    • Affected leg appears shortened, and the femoral head may be palpable in the gluteal region.
    • Often missed in patients with other severe injuries or in unconscious patients.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Femoral head displaced out of the acetabulum with the thigh internally rotated, obscuring the lesser trochanter.
    • Shenton's line is disrupted.
    • Look for bony fragments from the posterior acetabulum or femoral head.
    • CT scan may be needed to assess associated fractures.

Treatment:

  • Emergency Reduction:
    • Prompt reduction is essential to prevent avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
    • Most cases can be managed with closed reduction under general anesthesia.
    • Acetabular chip fractures often realign with successful reduction.
  • Open Reduction Indications:
    • Failure of closed reduction, especially in delayed cases.
    • Presence of intra-articular loose fragments hindering accurate reduction.
    • Large acetabular fragments from the weight-bearing area, causing hip instability.

Option A: USG has no role in identifying pelvic fracture and associated dislocation.

Option B: CT is the best modality for dislocations, also to see if it is associated with any fracture of the acetabulum or femoral head. (more likely) in this case.

Option C: MRI Is helpful in identifying associated Spinal Cord injury. However to check associated acetabulum, or femoral head fracture or Sciatic nerve injury CT Scan is a better Choice.

Option D: Though x rays are primary investigations done in all trauma cases, specific views like Judet views are not possible due to severe pain. Hence CT scan is always a better choice.

Key takeaways: FADIR deformity of hip and inability to move knee and ankle as well points towards posterior dislocation of hip with sciatic nerve injury which is Diagnosed with CT scan.

questions.text: All of the following are early complications of fractures except:
questions.solution:
Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (Sudeck's Dystrophy)

Definition: Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD), also known as Sudeck's Dystrophy, refers to a group of painful conditions that can develop as a consequence of trauma, even when the injury is relatively minor. The symptoms and signs experienced are often disproportionate to the severity of the trauma.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain: Persistent and severe.
  • Hyperesthesia: Increased sensitivity to stimuli.
  • Tenderness and Swelling: Particularly in the affected area.
  • Early Stage: Skin becomes red, shiny, and warm.
  • Later Stage: Progressive atrophy of the skin, muscles, and nails. Joint deformities and stiffness may also develop.
  • X-Ray Findings: Characteristic spotty rarefaction.

Treatment:

  • Medications: Beta-blockers may be beneficial in some cases.
  • Sympathetic Blocks: These may help in resistant cases.
  • Prolonged Care: long-term physiotherapy can be rewarding.

Option A, B and C: All are early complications of fractures.

Option D: Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD), also known as Sudeck's Dystrophy, Is Late Complication of fracture.

Key takeaways:

Early Complications of fracture:

  • Compartment syndrome
  • Crush syndrome
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • DVT & PE

questions.text: All of the following are radiological features of fracture non-union except:
questions.solution:
Delayed and Non-Union of Fractures

Definition:

  • Delayed Union: When a fracture takes longer than expected to heal but eventually unites.
  • Non-Union: When a fracture fails to unite after 6 months, with no further progression towards healing.

Clinical Features:

  • Delayed Union: Persistent fracture line visible on X-rays with inadequate callus formation.
  • Non-Union: Visible fracture line with minimal or absent bridging callus. The fracture ends may be smooth, rounded, and sclerotic, with possible obliteration of the medullary cavity.

Signs & Symptoms:

  • Persistent pain or pain on stressing the fracture.
  • Mobility at the fracture site (in non-union).
  • Increasing deformity.

Common Sites:

  • Neck of the femur
  • Scaphoid
  • Lower third of the tibia
  • Lower third of the ulna
  • Lateral condyle of the humerus

Types of Non-Union:

  1. Atrophic: Minimal or no callus formation.
  2. Hypertrophic: Callus is present but does not bridge the fracture site.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Findings: Persistent pain, abnormal mobility, and deformity.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Delayed Union: Visible fracture line with inadequate callus.
    • Non-Union: Smooth, sclerotic fracture ends with little bridging callus.
    • Advanced Imaging: 3D CT scans, stress X-rays, and weight-bearing X-rays may be required for detailed evaluation.

Consequences:

  • Persistent pain, deformity, abnormal mobility.
  • Refracture risk if stressed.

Treatment Options:

  1. Conservative Management: Continue physiotherapy and monitoring in delayed unions.
  2. Surgical Intervention:
    • Bone Grafting: Commonly used with internal fixation, using grafts from the iliac crest.
    • Excision of Fragments: Used where removal does not affect function (e.g., distal ulna).
    • Prosthetic Replacement: For non-union of the femoral neck in elderly patients.
  3. Ilizarov's Method: Ring external fixation for complex cases.
  4. No Treatment: In asymptomatic non-unions, especially in the scaphoid.

Option A, B & D: The fracture line is visible (Option B). There is little bridging callus (Option A). The fracture ends may be rounded, smooth and sclerotic (not lytic) (Option C). The medullary cavity may be obliterated (Option D).

Key takeaways:

The following are some of the radiological features suggestive of these complications:

  • Delayed union: The fracture line is visible. There may be inadequate callus bridging the fracture site.
  • Non-union: The fracture line is visible. There are little bridging calluses. The fracture ends may be rounded, smooth and sclerotic (not lytic). The medullary cavity may be obliterated.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Types of Casts and Their Uses:

Option A: Glass Holding Cast (Scaphoid Cast)

  • Extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, including the thumb up to the interphalangeal joint.
  • Wrist positioned in slight dorsiflexion and radial deviation (glass holding position).
  • Indications:
    • Used for scaphoid fractures.
    • In cases of widely displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation with Herbert's screw may be required.

Option B: PTB Cast (Patellar Tendon Bearing Cast)

  • Purpose: Used for conservative treatment of tibial shaft fractures.
  • Application:
    • After 6 weeks, once the fracture becomes 'sticky', the above-knee cast is replaced with a PTB cast.
    • Modern synthetic casting materials make application more convenient.
  • Follow-Up: As the fracture partly unites, the PTB cast can be replaced with removable plastic braces, allowing joint mobilization.

Option C: Cylindrical Cast

  • Description:
    • Extends from mid-thigh to just above the ankle, keeping the knee in full extension.
  • Indications:
    • Used for patella fractures and post quadriceps tendon repair surgeries.
    • Prevents knee flexion to allow healing.

Option D: U-Slab Cast

  • Description:
    • Extends from the base of the neck, over the shoulder, along the lateral arm, under the elbow, and to the medial side.
    • Molded laterally to prevent angulation and supported with a triangular sling.
  • Indications: Typically used for shoulder and upper arm fractures.
  • Duration: Removed after 6-8 weeks, followed by shoulder exercises.

Key takeaways:

Name of the cast and their use:

  • Minerva cast - Cervical spine disease
  • Risser's cast - Scoliosis
  • Turn-buckle cast - Scoliosis
  • Shoulder spica - Shoulder immobilization
  • U-slab - Fracture of the humerus
  • Hanging cast - Fracture of the humerus
  • Colle's cast - Colle's fracture
  • Hip spica - Fracture of the femur
  • Cylinder cast - Fracture of the patella
  • PTB cast - Fracture of the tibia

Glass holding cast - Scaphoid fracture

questions.text: The Judet view of x-ray is used for which fractures?
questions.solution:
Radiographic evaluation of acetabulum fractures:

Required Views:

  • Anteroposterior (AP) View:
    • Key anatomical landmarks include:
      • Iliopectineal line (limit of anterior column).
      • Ilioischial line (limit of posterior column).
      • Anterior wall and posterior wall.
      • Superior weight-bearing surface of the acetabulum.
      • Teardrop sign.
  • Iliac Oblique View (45-degree external rotation):
    • Best for visualizing:
      • Posterior column (ilioischial line).
      • Iliac wing
      • Anterior wall of the acetabulum.
      • (Mnemonic: I.O.W.A. = Iliac Oblique Wall Anterior).
  • Obturator Oblique View (45-degree internal rotation):
    • Best for evaluating:
      • Anterior column.
      • Posterior wall of the acetabulum.

Option A and C - Iliac crest and pubic rami are better visualized in Pelvis AP view.

Key takeaways:

Judet views are of two types:

  • Obturator oblique view for viewing Anterior column and posterior wall of acetabulum.
  • Iliac oblique view for viewing Posterior column and anterior wall of the acetabulum.

questions.text: A mass casualty is reported in a tertiary care centre with a history of a passenger bus involved in an RTA. The emergency department should be ready for initial radiologic imaging of the poly-trauma patients which includes:
questions.solution:
General Considerations in Polytrauma Management

Polytrauma Overview

  • Definition: Polytrauma refers to multiple traumatic injuries resulting from high-energy trauma, often associated with significant morbidity and mortality.
  • Management Protocols: Adherence to Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) protocols is critical for effective assessment and treatment.

ATLS Primary Survey (ABCs of Resuscitation)

  1. A-Airway Maintenance with Cervical Spine Protection:
  2. B-Breathing and Ventilation:
  3. C-Circulation with Hemorrhage Control:
  4. D-Disability and Neurologic Assessment:
  5. E-Exposure and Environmental Control:

Initial Radiologic Workup

  • During or Immediately After the Primary Survey:
    • Standard Imaging Includes: (Option A, B, C and D)
      • Anteroposterior (AP) chest radiograph.
      • AP pelvis radiograph.
      • Lateral cervical spine radiograph (must include C7-T1 junction for adequacy).

Advanced Imaging

  1. Computed Tomography (CT) Scan:
    • Advantages:
      1. Superior availability and processing speed.
      2. Replacing lateral cervical spine radiographs for trauma evaluation.
      3. Sagittal views detect approximately 85% of cervical spine fractures.
    • Indications:
      1. Evaluation of C1 fractures.
      2. Assessing bone integrity in the spinal canal.
    • Limitations:
      1. May miss axial plane fractures (e.g., Type II odontoid fractures).
  2. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
    • Benefits:
      1. Superior for detecting soft tissue abnormalities.
      2. Evaluates the integrity of the posterior longitudinal complex (PLC).
      3. Detects disc herniations, canal compromise, spinal cord injury, edema, and epidural hematomas.
    • Controversial Use:
      1. Increasingly used for cervical spine "clearance", but its routine use remains debated.

Secondary Survey

  • Performed After Primary Survey and Initial Imaging:
    • Comprehensive head-to-toe evaluation of each body region.
    • Focus:
      • Neurological Examination:
        • Assess the lowest remaining functional level.
        • Check for sacral sparing, indicating an incomplete spinal cord injury.
        • Neurologic level defined by the most cephalad level with normal bilateral motor and sensory function
      • Investigate:
        • Facial injuries.
        • Hypotension.
        • Localized tenderness or muscle spasm.

Additional Imaging Based on Secondary Survey

  • Complete Cervical Spine Series (C1-T1):
    • Indicated if there are findings from the secondary survey that suggest further spinal injury.
    • Multiple-Level Injuries:
      • Occur in 10%-20% of trauma cases.

Reassessment

  • If the patient's condition deteriorates during the secondary survey, reinitiate the primary survey to reassess and stabilize the patient.

Key takeaways:

CT of the cervical spine has replaced the lateral cervical spine radiograph in the standard trauma series for spine clearance. Radiography of the pelvis and chest remains the standard. The other examinations may be indicated by the clinical scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principle of damage control orthopedics?
questions.solution:
Early Total Care vs. Damage Control Orthopaedics

Early Total Care involves definitive treatment of long bone fractures soon after injury (Option A). However, there is ongoing debate about the optimal method for fracture management, and further research is needed to establish the best approach for different situations.

Damage Control Orthopaedics (DCO), on the other hand, focuses on staging the definitive care of the patient to prevent exacerbating the early physiological insult, especially in critically injured patients. (Option C)

Key Principles of Damage Control Orthopaedics:

  • Goal: To avoid the "second hit" of additional trauma from surgery during the early acute inflammatory phase.
  • Acute Inflammatory Response:
    • Trauma triggers a surge in inflammatory mediators, which peak between 2–5 days post-injury. (Option D)
    • After the initial release of cytokines and other mediators, leukocytes become "primed" and can be easily activated by further trauma, such as surgery, potentially leading to complications like multisystem organ failure or Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).
  • Treatment Approach:
    • Priority: During the acute inflammatory phase, only life-threatening injuries should be treated.
    • Emergent and Urgent Conditions:
      • Compartment syndrome
      • Fractures associated with vascular injury
      • Unreduced dislocations
      • Long bone fractures
      • Open fractures
      • Unstable spine fractures
    • Acute Stabilization:
      • Method: Primarily achieved through external fixation. (Option B)
      • Conversion Timeline for Fractures:
        • Femur Fractures: Conversion from external fixator to intramedullary (IM) nail should be done within 3 weeks.
        • Tibia Fractures: Conversion should occur within 7 to 10 days. If a longer period is necessary, a staged approach is recommended: removing the external fixator first, then nailing several days later.

Option A: Early Total Care involves definitive treatment of long bone fractures soon after injury.

Option B: long bone fracture are Primarily achieved through external fixation.

Option C: Damage Control Orthopaedics (DCO), on the other hand, focuses on staging the definitive care of the patient to prevent exacerbating the early physiological insult, especially in critically injured patients.

Option D: Trauma triggers a surge in inflammatory mediators, which peak between 2-5 days post-injury.

Key takeaways:

  • Damage control orthopaedic principles involve staging the definitive care of the patient to avoid adding to the early overall physiologic insult.
  • To minimize the additional trauma from surgery (second hit), traumatologists often treat only potentially life-threatening injuries during this acute inflammatory window.
  • Acute stabilization is achieved primarily via external fixation.

choices.text: At any time as long as the pin sites are clean

questions.text: When can a femoral external fixator placed for polytrauma as a part of damage control orthopaedics, be safely converted to definitive intramedullary nail fixation?
questions.solution:
The advantages of staged treatment in polytrauma cases according to DCO are:

  • Relief of pain, by preventing movement at the fracture.
  • Prevention of further damage to skin, soft tissues and neurovascular bundle of the injured extremity.
  • Prevention of complications such as fat embolism and hypovolemic shock.
  • Transportation of the patient was made easier.

Inflammatory Response After Trauma

  1. Surge in Inflammatory Mediators:
    • Trauma triggers a surge in inflammatory mediators (e.g., cytokines), which peaks between 2-5 days post-injury.
  2. Leukocyte Activation:
    • Following this initial burst, leukocytes become "primed" and are highly susceptible to activation by additional trauma, such as surgery.
    • This heightened state can lead to severe complications, including:
      • Multisystem Organ Failure
      • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  3. Management Strategy During Acute Phase:
    • To avoid further physiological stress ("second hit"), traumatologists typically limit interventions to treating only potentially life-threatening injuries during this critical inflammatory window.

Option A, B & D:

Current studies indicate safe conversion of femoral fixators within 3 weeks (Option B,C) and tibial fixators within 7-10 days (Option A) in polytrauma patients if pin sites are clean; otherwise, staged removal with treatment of the pin sites can safely be performed.

Key takeaways:

Current studies indicate safe conversion of femoral fixators within 3 weeks and tibial fixators within 7-10 days in polytrauma patients if pin sites are clean; otherwise, staged removal with treatment of the pin sites can safely be performed.

questions.text: Straddle fractures are best described by:
questions.solution:
Straddle Fracture

Definition (Option A, B, C and D):

A straddle fracture is characterized by bilateral fractures of both the superior and inferior pubic rami. It resembles a "straddle" position due to its symmetrical nature and is typically associated with high-energy trauma.

Common Causes:

  • Direct Trauma: Often results from falls from a height or motor vehicle accidents.
  • Riding Accidents: Common in horseback riding or biking incidents, where sudden impact forces the pelvis against the saddle or bike frame.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms:
    • Pain localized to the pelvic area, especially over the fracture site.
    • Tenderness and bruising over the pubic region.
    • Associated injuries may cause difficulty urinating or hematuria (blood in urine).
  • Silent Presentation:
    • In patients with multiple injuries, the fracture may not be immediately apparent due to lack of specific complaints.
    • Often detected during a routine pelvic compression test assessing pelvic stability.

Diagnostic Approach:

  • Imaging:
    • Initial diagnosis is made using pelvic X-rays.
    • CT scans may be required to evaluate the extent of the fracture and plan surgical intervention.

Management:

  • Conservative Treatment:
    • Recommended for undisplaced or minimally displaced fractures.
    • Involves bed rest, pain management, and use of pelvic binders or braces.
    • Gradual weight-bearing and physiotherapy initiated as pain subsides.
  • Surgical Intervention:
    • Required for significantly displaced fractures or those involving the pubic symphysis or acetabulum.
    • Plating is used to stabilize fractured segments and facilitate earlier mobilization.
    • Surgery is also necessary for complications such as bladder or urethral injuries.

Key takeaways:

Straddle Fracture:

  • Definition: Bilateral fractures of the superior and inferior pubic rami.
  • Common Cause: Typically results from falls or impacts while riding a bike or horse.
  • Conservative Treatment: For undisplaced or minimally displaced fractures.
  • Surgical Intervention: Plating may be required if the fracture extends to the pubic symphysis or acetabulum.

questions.text: A 45 yr man collided with a truck while driving on a highway and was brought to emergency with multiple injuries and hypovolemic shock. CT screening shows open book type pelvic injury along with abdominal visceral injuries as well. All of the following are necessary steps in management except:
questions.solution:
1. Primary Assessment of polytrauma Patient

Standard ABCDE approach for initial assessment

2. Secondary assessment

Extremities and Pelvis Evaluation:

  • Identify all injuries to the extremities and pelvis.
  • Carefully assess distal neurovascular status (pulse, sensation, movement) in each limb.
  • Check for pelvic instability by assessing leg length discrepancy, noting any shortening or abnormal rotation of the lower extremities.

Pelvic Instability Assessment (AP-LC Test):

  • Perform the AP-LC test once, involving gentle internal and external rotation of the pelvis to assess for instability.
  • Be cautious as excessive manipulation can disrupt clot formation.

Hemorrhage and Contusions:

  • Look for signs of significant bleeding, such as massive flank or buttock contusions and swelling.
  • Remember, "The first clot is the best clot". Disruption of the initial clot can complicate subsequent bleeding control due to hemodilution and depletion of clotting factors.

Palpation for Fractures and Defects:

  • Palpate the posterior pelvis for hematomas, defects indicating fractures, or sacroiliac joint dislocations.
  • Check the pubic symphysis for any palpable defects.

Inspection for Open Fractures:

  • Inspect the perineum carefully for signs of open fractures or lacerations.

Rectal and Vaginal Examination:

  • Perform a digital rectal exam in all trauma patients with suspected pelvic ring disruption.
  • For women, a vaginal exam is also necessary to rule out perforations.
  • Missed rectal or vaginal injuries in pelvic trauma can lead to severe complications and poor prognosis.

Secondary assessment:

Options for immediate hemorrhage control in pelvic injuries include:

  1. Application of military antishock trousers (MAST). This is typically performed in the field.
  2. Wrapping of a pelvic binder circumferentially around the pelvis (or sheet if a binder is not available). This should be applied at the level of the trochanters to provide access to the abdomen.
  3. Consider the application of a bean bag.
  4. Consider angiography or embolization if the hemorrhage continues despite closing of the pelvic volume.
  5. Consider application of a pelvic C-clamp (posterior).
  6. Consider an anterior external fixator.
  7. Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF): This may be undertaken if the patient is undergoing emergency laparotomy for other indications but it is frequently contraindicated by itself because loss of the tamponade effect may encourage further hemorrhage.
  8. Open packing of the retroperitoneum is an option in the unstable patient who is brought to the operating room for laparotomy and exploration.

Key takeaways:

Options for immediate hemorrhage control in pelvic injuries include:

  • Wrapping of a pelvic binder circumferentially around the pelvis (or sheet if a binder is not available). This should be applied at the level of the trochanters to provide access to the abdomen.
  • Consider an anterior external fixator.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF): This may be undertaken if the patient is undergoing emergency laparotomy for other indications but it is frequently contraindicated by itself because loss of the tamponade effect may encourage further hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 20 yr old footballer sustained an injury to left knee while playing football. He is having pain and feeling of giving away over back and outer aspect of the knee. MRI shows injury to PCL and PLC both. Which clinical test will be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tibial External Rotation (Dial) Test for Posterolateral Knee Instability

Purpose:

  • Assesses posterolateral instability of the knee by measuring the external rotation of the tibia relative to the femur at different angles of knee flexion.

Procedure:

  1. Patient Position:
    • Can be performed with the patient in a supine or prone position.
  2. Measurement Points:
    • External rotation is measured at 30 degrees and 90 degrees of knee flexion.
  3. External Rotation Measurement:
    • Use the medial border of the foot in its neutral position as a reference.
    • Apply an external rotational force to the foot and measure the foot-thigh angle relative to the femur axis.
    • Compare the degree of external rotation with the opposite (uninjured) leg.

Interpretation of Results:

  1. A difference of 10 degrees or more in external rotation between the injured and uninjured knees is considered pathologic.
  2. Increased External Rotation at 30 Degrees Only:
    • Indicates an isolated injury to the posterolateral corner.
  3. Increased External Rotation at Both 30 and 90 Degrees:
    • Indicates injury to both the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) and the posterolateral corner.

Special Considerations:

  1. Results of the dial test may be unreliable in the presence of medial instability, such as a torn medial collateral ligament (MCL).
  2. Reduction with Anterior Force:
    • Applying an anterior force to reduce the tibia can enhance detection of posterolateral rotatory instability, especially in the presence of PCL injuries.

Option A: Lachman test is done for Checking ACL Injuries.

Option B: Mc murray test Is done for Checking Meniscal Pathologies.

Option D: Pivot shift test is done for Checking ACL Injuries.

Key takeaways:

  • The purpose of the Dial Test is to diagnose Posterolateral Knee injury, as well as to differentiate between isolated Postero-lateral corner (PLC) injury and combination of PLC and Posterior Cruciate Ligament injury (PCL).
  • For an isolated PCL tear, the posterior drawer test or sag tests are more relevant.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient presents to you with pain over right knee along with instability while walking. H/o hit by a 2 wheeler over the outer aspect of the right knee 1 day back. Clinical examination reveals a positive valgus stress at 30 degree flexion. Your diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Knee Ligament Injuries

  1. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) - Option A
    • Mechanism: Injured by a valgus force (abduction of the leg on the femur).
    • Common Injury Site: Often ruptured from its femoral attachment.
  2. Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) - Option C
    • Mechanism: Damaged by a varus force (adduction of the tibia on the femur), opposite to the mechanism for MCL injury.
    • Common Injury Site: Usually avulsed from the head of the fibula along with a piece of bone.
  3. Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) - Option B
    • Mechanism: Commonly ruptured due to a twisting force on a semi-flexed knee.
    • Associated Injuries: Often occurs with tears of the medial or lateral collateral ligaments.
    • O'Donoghue Triad: A combination of injuries involving the medial collateral ligament, medial meniscus, and anterior cruciate ligament.
  4. Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) - Option D
    • Mechanism: Damaged when the anterior aspect of the tibia is struck while the knee is semi-flexed, pushing the tibia backwards relative to the femur.

Key takeaways:

  • Medial collateral ligament: It is damaged if the injuring force has the effect of abducting the leg on the femur (valgus force). It ruptures most commonly from its femoral attachment. Diagnosed by Valgus stress test at 30 degree Knee Flexion.

questions.text: A young gym enthusiast was lifting heavy weights in the gym and he suddenly felt a give away and pop in the elbow with severe pain. An MRI showed rupture of distal end of biceps from its insertion. What classic clinical sign will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Distal Biceps Tendon Injury

Mechanism

  • Cause: Eccentric loading of the flexed elbow during:
    • Manual labor.
    • Weight lifting.
    • Poorly executed lifting activities.

Demographics

  • Prevalence: Almost exclusively in middle-aged males.

Risk Factors

  • Associated Factors:
    • Steroid use.
    • Tobacco use.

Presentation

  • Symptoms:
    • Patients may report a painful "pop" deep in the proximal forearm.

Physical Examination

  • Strength Assessment:
    • Diminished supination strength more than flexion strength (biceps is the main forearm supinator; brachialis is the main elbow flexor).
  • Tests:
    • Abnormal hook test result.
  • Prognosis:
    • If untreated, approximately 50% supination and 70% flexion strength may be regained by 1 year.

Partial Ruptures

  • Location: Occur on the radial side of the tuberosity footprint due to its function as a supinator.
  • Initial Treatment: Nonoperative management with rest, NSAIDs, and therapy.
  • Possible Future Intervention: May require detachment, debridement, and reattachment.

Radiology - MRI is used to confirm diagnosis and differentiate between complete and partial ruptures.

Surgical Treatment

  • Indication: Recommended for active individuals with complete rupture to regain strength.
  • Reattachment: To the radial aspect of the tuberosity.
  • Techniques:
    • Single-Incision: Effective but risk of neurologic injury (lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve in up to 25% of cases).
    • Two-Incision: Also effective but risk of radioulnar synostosis.

Fixation Methods

  • Options:
    • Bone trough/drill holes.
    • Suture anchors.
    • Interference screw.
    • Titanium fixation button (Endobutton).

Chronic Injuries

  • Definition: Injuries lasting more than 6 weeks.
  • Treatment Options: Tendon autograft or allograft augmentation.
  • Strength Recovery: Generally less than with acute repair using native tendon.

Postoperative Care

  • Rehabilitation: Strengthening exercises should be avoided for approximately 8-10 weeks postoperatively.

Option A - When the biceps tendon ruptures proximally near the shoulder, the torn tendon can no longer keep the muscle tight and hence the muscle belly will bulge in the lower arm with a dent closer to shoulder. This is called popeye sign, which can be made more obvious by contracting the muscle.

Option B - Exact opposite sign is seen in distal end biceps rupture where the muscle bulges in the upper arm with a dent near the elbow. This is called reverse popeye sign.

Option C & D: There are no named signs as mentioned in option C and D.

Key takeaways:

  • When the biceps tendon ruptures proximally near the shoulder, the torn tendon can no longer keep the muscle tight and hence the muscle belly will bulge in the lower arm with a dent closer to shoulder. This is called popeye sign, which can be made more obvious by contracting the muscle.
  • Exact opposite sign is seen in distal end biceps rupture where the muscle bulges in the upper arm with a dent near the elbow. This is called reverse popeye sign.

questions.text: A pedestrian was hit by the bumper of a car at high velocity while he was walking on the road. His x-ray was normal but he was having gross knee swelling. MRI revealed injury to ACL, MCL and medial meniscus. What is this injury called?
questions.solution:
• Often the injury to medial collateral ligament, medial meniscus and anterior cruciate ligament occur together. This is called the O'Donoghue triad. Aka as Unhappy / Terrible triad of knee.

Knee Ligament Injury

Specific Ligament Injuries

  • Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL):
    • Injury Mechanism: Result of an abducting force on the leg (valgus force).
    • Common Rupture Site: Typically ruptures from its femoral attachment.
  • Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL):
    • Injury Mechanism: Result of adduction of the tibia on the femur (varus force).
    • Common Rupture Site: Often avulsed from the head of the fibula with a piece of bone.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL):
    • Injury Mechanism: Most commonly ruptured due to twisting forces on a semi-flexed knee.
    • Associated Injuries: Frequently occurs alongside tears of the MCL and/or lateral collateral ligaments.
    • O'Donoghue Triad (Option A): Injury to the MCL, medial meniscus, and ACL occurring together.
  • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL):
    • Injury Mechanism: Damaged when the anterior aspect of the tibia is struck while the knee is semi-flexed, forcing the tibia backwards on the femur.

Key takeaways:

  • Often the injury to medial collateral ligament, medial meniscus and anterior cruciate ligament occur together. This is called the O'Donoghue triad.
  • These are actually very rare and very difficult to treat as well as associated with inferior outcomes as well. Hence this combination of injury is also called the Unhappy/Terrible triad of knee as well.
  • However in common practice, combination injury of ACL, MCL and lateral meniscus is more commonly seen than this triad.
